item.content:encoded:
As you know I’ll want to sell online, and I hate using centralized (and unnecessarily expensive) services: so I had to write my own small backend to handle Stripe payments coming in. The SDK is available in many languages but for learning I picked up Ruby. Problem is, it would’ve taken atleast days to get up and running with my own code from scratch. Luckily, I’ve got an idea.

The feared AI

I went onto ChatGPT and told it to handle Stripe payments with Ruby and then send a request to Mautic with the payment informations. It, literally did it. No hassle, no nothing: I only had to do some touch-ups (and I obviously had to setup a VPS beforehand). Is it perfect code? Probably not: but I’ve never seen a human write something flawless for the first time…

Do we even need programmers?

Sort of. You see at the moment, this is a great guiding tool. Yeah, it will surely develop. It will get to a point when I will tell it what to do and it will even handle the VPS creation. Still, someone needs to supervise this process: heck, someone needs to tell it the goals.

Programming is dead. Long live programming!

Traditional programming has ceased to exist. Isn’t programming just telling instructions to a computer (very much a simplified description)? Just because we’ve made a (sort of) compiler that can translate English to specific instructions that notion didn’t change. We’re just going to an even higher level than let’s say Python!

What I just outlined is still the future. For now, it’s a great helping tool.

…and I plan to use it. I’ve applied to Github’s student program to get free access, while I also found a vim plugin.

UPDATE: Github doesn’t really want me in their student program as I got rejected already. I’ll be sure to try again but their process is very bad for smaller schools. Also, they could be clearer on the problems they’ve with my application. I can still test Copilot: there’s a 30-day trial.
